security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable code. Static scanner flagged text patterns in markdown files (backticks for code formatting, URLs in references, technical terms in documentation). All 45 detected patterns are FALSE POSITIVES - markdown documentation cannot execute commands, make network calls, or contain exploitable code. Safe for publication.

low_findings.title: Documentation Pattern False Positives
low_findings.description: Static scanner incorrectly flagged text patterns in markdown files. Backticks are markdown code formatting, not shell execution. URLs are documentation references, not network calls. Technical term mentions are not actual cryptographic code.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: All files are markdown documentation (.md) that cannot execute code. Pattern matching on documentation text is inappropriate - backticks format code, URLs are references, technical terms are explanatory text.

content.value_statement: Frontend code reviews help developers catch bugs and anti-patterns before deployment. This skill provides automated checklist-based reviews for TypeScript, JavaScript, TSX, and JSX files using industry best practices.
actual_capabilities: Review TypeScript and JavaScript files (TSX, JSX) using a comprehensive checklist
Check code quality rules including type safety, naming conventions, and component patterns
Identify business logic issues such as error handling gaps and missing validations
Evaluate performance concerns like unnecessary re-renders and expensive operations
limitations: Only supports frontend file types (TSX, TS, JSX, JS) - does not review backend code
Does not execute or test code - provides static analysis only
Does not modify files - only reports findings without making changes

use_cases.title: Quick File Review
use_cases.description: Request a focused review of a single file to get immediate feedback on code quality and potential issues.
use_cases.target_user: Developers needing fast feedback on specific files

use_cases.title: Pull Request Review
use_cases.description: Review all changed files in a pull request to ensure code meets quality standards before merging.

use_cases.title: Legacy Code Assessment
use_cases.description: Evaluate older codebases to identify technical debt and prioritize refactoring efforts.

best_practices: Use the skill for both focused single-file reviews and comprehensive multi-file assessments to catch different types of issues
Review findings in context - some suggestions may not apply to your specific use case or coding standards
Combine automated reviews with manual testing to ensure code works correctly in addition to being well-structured
anti_patterns: Avoid requesting reviews of non-frontend files (Python, Go, etc.) - the skill is optimized for TS/JS ecosystems
Do not expect the skill to execute or test your code - it provides static analysis only
Avoid ignoring findings related to TypeScript types - strict typing prevents runtime errors

faq.question: What file types does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill supports TypeScript (.ts), JavaScript (.js), TypeScript React (.tsx), and JavaScript React (.jsx) files.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. The skill only analyzes and reports findings. It does not modify, refactor, or write any code changes.

faq.question: Can I use this for backend code reviews?
faq.answer: No. This skill is specifically designed for frontend code. Use language-specific review tools for Python, Go, or other backend languages.

faq.question: How does this compare to ESLint?
faq.answer: This skill complements ESLint by providing contextual feedback on business logic, architecture decisions, and code patterns that automated tools cannot evaluate.

faq.question: Can I customize the review checklist?
faq.answer: The skill uses built-in reference documents (business-logic.md, code-quality.md, performance.md). Review focus can be adjusted through prompt templates.

faq.question: Does this skill work with Next.js and React?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes React-specific checks for hooks usage, component patterns, and framework-specific best practices.
